Case 105: - Start: 2024-03-01 08:25 - End: 2024-03-03 09:30 Duration: 2 days + 1 hour 5 minutes? So durations: - Case 101: 2.25 hours - Case 102: 25.17 hours - Case 103: 1.33 hours - Case 104: 24.17 hours - Case 105: 49.08 hours

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Note that the 19h gaps appear in multiple cases and likely represent overnight delays. But why do some tickets have overnight delays? Possibly because they were not resolved by end of business day. For example, in case 102, investigation started at 14:00, and maybe it required more time, so it carried over to next day. In case 104, investigation started at 13:00, but resolution happened next morning. In case 105, after escalation, the second investigation started at 14:00 next day, and then resolution next morning again. It seems that if a ticket is not resolved by the end of the business day, it gets postponed to the next day, adding roughly 15-16 hours of non-working time. This is a major factor in long cycle times. Also, there are significant within-day delays: e.g., in case 104, 3.5 hours from Assign to Investigate. This could be due to agent workload or ticket prioritization. Another factor: escalations lead to additional handoffs and possibly queueing in the Level-2 team. In case 105, the escalation happened at 10:00, but the Level-2 agent didnt start investigation until 14:00 the next day. Thats a very long wait. Possibly Level-2 team has limited capacity or works on a different schedule.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Insights: 1. Escalations significantly increase resolution time, not only due to additional processing but also due to handoff delays and potential queueing for specialized agents. 2. Long waiting times between assignment and investigation indicate that Level-1 agents might be overloaded, leading to delays in starting work on new tickets. 3. Tickets that are not resolved within the same business day incur substantial overnight delays, which greatly extend the total cycle time. This suggests that there may be no follow-up or urgency to resolve tickets before the end of the day. 4. The process might benefit from better prioritization and scheduling to avoid carrying over tickets to the next day. Recommendations: 1. Monitor and reduce handoff times between teams. For escalations, ensure that Level-2 agents are notified promptly and have clear service level agreements (SLAs) for picking up escalated tickets. 2. Analyze workload distribution among Level-1 agents to ensure that tickets are assigned evenly and agents have capacity to start investigation promptly after assignment. 3. Implement policies or incentives to encourage resolution of tickets within the same business day, especially for tickets that are received early in the day. This could involve setting deadlines or prioritizing tickets based on their age. 4. Consider extending support hours or having overlapping shifts to handle tickets that would otherwise wait overnight. 5. For tickets that require escalation, consider having Level-1 agents gather more information upfront to reduce the time needed by Level-2 agents, or implement a parallel processing approach where Level-2 agents are involved earlier. 6. Use process mining to identify bottlenecks and continuously monitor performance metrics like time between activities.
